title: Deca Loših Muzičara
text:
Deca Loših Muzičara (; trans. "Bad Musicians' Children"), often abbreviated to DLM, are a <a href="funk%20rock">funk rock</a> band from <a href="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>. They were one of the most popular Serbian bands in the early 1990s. Most DLM songs are fast and furious funk rock, but melodic, adorned with <a href="trumpet">trumpet</a> and <a href="saxophone">saxophone</a> lines.
History.
1989-2009.
The band was formed in 1988 by Jova Jović (<a href="electric%20guitar">guitar</a>), Aleksandar Siljanovski "Silja" (vocals), Vladan Miljković Milje (<a href="saxophone">saxophone</a>), Zoran Milivojević Mikac (<a href="drum%20kit">drums</a>), Zoran Živković (<a href="bass%20guitar">bass guitar</a>), Đorđe Anđelić Kića (<a href="trumpet">trumpet</a>) and Ivan Blagojević "Uške" (trumpet). Saxophonist Dušan Petrović was also a temporary band member, but soon moved to <a href="Plejboj">Plejboj</a>. After Blagojević's departute, trumpet player Bora Veličković joined the band. The band won the first place at the last Youth Festival in <a href="Subotica">Subotica</a> in 1990, and the song "Doživotno osuđen na ljubav" ("Sentenced to Love for Life ") was published on the festival compilation album.
The recording of the band's debut album "Dobar dan" ("Good day"), produced by Vlada Žeželj, was finished in early 1992, but it was a year later that the album was released. Influenced by the, at the time popular, American rock sound and colored with <a href="brass%20section">brass</a> sections, with the prominent songs "Kreditna kartica" ("Credit card"), which partially features lyrics in <a href="Slovene%20language">Slovene</a> as Siljanovski spoke the language, "Zeka" ("Bunny"), "Ljubomora" ("Jealousy")and "Mara", provided the band's growing popularity. The album also featured two bonus tracks, "Ja sam tvoj čovek" ("I am your man") and "Njena je, njena je" ("It belongs to her, it belongs to her"). The band also represented <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> at the "Music Days" festival held in <a href="Strasbourg">Strasbourg</a>. In the meantime, the band's brass section started recording and performing with the <a href="Oi%21">oi! punk rock</a> band <a href="Direktori">Direktori</a>. The band also appeared in the <a href="Sr%C4%91an%20Dragojevi%C4%87">Srđan Dragojević</a> movie "Dva sata kvalitetnog TV programa" ("Two hours of quality TV programme") performing a cover version of <a href="Metak%20%28band%29">Metak</a> song "Da mi je biti morski pas" ("If I were a shark").
The second album, "Prolećni dan" ("A spring day"), accompanied with songs "Vlade Divac", devoted to the <a href="Vlade%20Divac">famous basketball player</a>, "Konji ritma" ("Rhythm horses") and the title track became essential part of the band's live performances. The song "Ubiše Pabla" ("Pablo got killed") featured improvised lyrics in <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a>. The album was produced by the band themselves, and Puroni on percussion and Dež Molnar on saxophone appeared as guests on the album. The band also recorded a cover version of the <a href="AC/DC">AC/DC</a> single "<a href="Let%20There%20Be%20Rock%20%28song%29">Let There Be Rock</a>", which was released on the various artists compilation "Ovo je zemlja za nas?!?" ("This is the land for us?!?") and released by BOOM 93, and appeared on the Radio Index various artists compilation "Nas slušaju svi, mi ne slušamo nikoga" ("Everybody listens to us, we listen to nobody") with a live version of "Dobar dan" ("Good day"), recorded at <a href="Dom%20omladine%20Beograda">Dom Omladine in Belgrade</a> and "Vi što maštate o sreći" ("You who dream of happiness").
The 1998 album "Virus" featured the music the band recorded for the <a href="Du%C5%A1an%20Kova%C4%8Devi%C4%87">Dušan Kovačević</a> theater play of the same name. The album featured the songs, "Ljubav" ("Love"), featuring lead vocals by the starring actor Ivan Jevtović, and "Dezodorans" ("Deodorant"), and the rest of the released material consisted of instrumental tracks, including a cover version of <a href="Maurice%20Ravel">Maurice Ravel</a>'s "<a href="Bol%C3%A9ro">Boléro</a>". During the same year, the band wrote music for another play, <a href="Sini%C5%A1a%20Kova%C4%8Devi%C4%87">Siniša Kovačević</a>'s "Kraljević Marko", in which the band appeared as live performers and acting minor roles. The band also appeared on the "Drž'te jih! To nisu Niet!!!" ("Get 'Em! They Are Not Niet") tribute album to the Slovenian band <a href="Niet">Niet</a>, with the song "Zastave" ("Flags").
After an 8-year discography break, in 2005, the band recorded a new album "...gde cveta samsung žut" ("... where the yellow <a href="Samsung%20Group">samsung</a> blooms") in a new lineup. Beside Siljanovski, Milivojević, Živković and Veličković, the new members were <a href="trombone">trombonist</a> Mihajlo Bogosavljević, a former Havana Whispers member and <a href="Del%20Arno%20Band">Del Arno Band</a> guitarist, and guitarist Goran Đorđević "Đole". The song lyrics for the album were written by Miljković, who in the meantime had moved to <a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>. During the Spring of the following year, Siljanovski left the band and was replaced by Ivan Jevtović, a long-time friend of the band.
In late June 2009, the band officially announced their disbandment, stating no specific reason.
2011-present.
In December 2011, the band reunited, having their reunion performance at the Concert of the Year in <a href="Novi%20Sad">Novi Sad</a> on 10 December. The band celebrated 20 years since the release of their debut album with a performance on Vračar Rocks Festival on 22 March 2012. In March 2013, the band celebrated 25 years since the beginning of their career by releasing the song "Flora & Fauna".
In March 2015, Jevtović left the band. Both him and the rest of the members stated that they mutually agreed to part ways due to Jevtović's acting obligations, and that they would probably cooperate again in the future. The band's new vocalist became Nenad Petrović, with whom the band performed for the first time on May 2, 2015 in <a href="Novi%20Sad">Novi Sad</a>.
Legacy.
In 2006, the song "Dobardan!" was ranked No. 36 on the <a href="B92%20Top%20100%20Domestic%20Songs">B92 Top 100 Domestic Songs</a> list.
In 2011, the song "Prolećni dan" was polled, by the listeners of <a href="Radio%20Belgrade">Radio 202</a>, one of 60 greatest songs released by <a href="PGP-RTB">PGP-RTB</a>/<a href="PGP-RTS">PGP-RTS</a> during the sixty years of the label's existence.
